<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 278, 170, 293]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 297, 379, 314]]<|/det|>
Paper 4 A Level Structured Questions  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 278, 905, 293]]<|/det|>
9702/42  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 299, 905, 314]]<|/det|>
May/June 2019

2 hours  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 338, 415, 355]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 359, 366, 375]]<|/det|>
No Additional Materials are required.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 390, 386, 408]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 715, 490]]<|/det|>
Write your centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in. Write in dark blue or black pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid. DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 500, 255, 516]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 527, 758, 559]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used. You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 567, 758, 598]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 73, 126, 88]]<|/det|>
## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 103, 668, 560]]<|/det|>
speed of light in free space \(c = 3.00\times 10^{8}\mathrm{m s}^{- 1}\) permeability of free space \(\mu_{0} = 4\pi \times 10^{- 7}\mathrm{Hm}^{- 1}\) permittivity of free space \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85\times 10^{- 12}\mathrm{Fm}^{- 1}\) \((\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}} = 8.99\times 10^{9}\mathrm{mF}^{- 1})\) elementary charge \(e = 1.60\times 10^{- 19}\mathrm{C}\) the Planck constant \(h = 6.63\times 10^{- 34}\mathrm{Js}\) unified atomic mass unit \(1u = 1.66\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of electron \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11\times 10^{- 31}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of proton \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) molar gas constant \(R = 8.31\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Avogadro constant \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02\times 10^{23}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Boltzmann constant \(k = 1.38\times 10^{- 23}\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant \(G = 6.67\times 10^{- 11}\mathrm{Nm}^{2}\mathrm{kg}^{- 2}\) acceleration of free fall \(g = 9.81\mathrm{m s}^{- 2}\)

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 107, 561, 144]]<|/det|>
\[s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^{2}\] \[\nu^{2} = u^{2} + 2as\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 163, 527, 180]]<|/det|>
\[W = \rho \Delta V\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 195, 537, 225]]<|/det|>
\[\phi = -\frac{Gm}{r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 235, 525, 252]]<|/det|>
\[p = \rho gh\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 262, 561, 294]]<|/det|>
\[p = \frac{1}{3}\frac{Nm}{V}\langle c^2\rangle\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 305, 536, 322]]<|/det|>
\[a = -\omega^2 x\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 339, 608, 375]]<|/det|>
\[\nu = \nu_{0}\cos \omega t\] \[\nu = \pm \omega \sqrt{(\chi_{0}^{2} - \chi^{2})}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 380, 537, 415]]<|/det|>
\[f_{0} = \frac{f_{s}V}{\nu \pm \nu_{s}}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 425, 537, 459]]<|/det|>
\[V = \frac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 467, 628, 486]]<|/det|>
\[1 / C = 1 / C_{1} + 1 / C_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 500, 598, 518]]<|/det|>
\[C = C_{1} + C_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 529, 527, 555]]<|/det|>
\[W = \frac{1}{2} QV\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 570, 531, 587]]<|/det|>
\[I = A n v q\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 603, 598, 621]]<|/det|>
\[R = R_{1} + R_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 636, 628, 655]]<|/det|>
\[1 / R = 1 / R_{1} + 1 / R_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 668, 520, 700]]<|/det|>
\[V_{\mathrm{H}} = \frac{BI}{ntq}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 714, 558, 732]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_{0}\sin \omega t\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 747, 578, 766]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_{0}\exp (-\lambda t)\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 775, 536, 810]]<|/det|>
\[\lambda = \frac{0.693}{t_{\frac{1}{2}}}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[295, 72, 700, 91]]<|/det|>
Answer **all** the questions in the spaces provided.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 103, 96, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 144, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 667, 121]]<|/det|>
Two point masses are separated by a distance \(x\) in a vacuum.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 735, 136]]<|/det|>
State an expression for the force \(F\) between the two masses \(M\) and \(m\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 134, 504, 152]]<|/det|>
State the name of any other symbol used.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 257, 144, 276]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 256, 735, 276]]<|/det|>
A small sphere S is attached to one end of a rod, as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 288, 850, 485]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[722, 478, 848, 497]]<|/det|>
<form>view from side</form>

<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 520, 591, 538]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 551, 603, 568]]<|/det|>
The rod hangs from a vertical thread and is horizontal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 566, 685, 584]]<|/det|>
The distance from the centre of sphere S to the thread is 8.0 cm.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 597, 695, 616]]<|/det|>
A large sphere L is placed near to sphere S, as shown in Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 625, 845, 880]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 894, 591, 913]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.2 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
There is a force of attraction between spheres S and L, causing sphere S to move through a distance of \(1.2 \text{mm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 638, 121]]<|/det|>
The line joining the centres of S and L is normal to the rod.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 134, 181, 153]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 133, 761, 152]]<|/det|>
Show that the angle \(\theta\) through which the rod rotates is \(1.5 \times 10^{-2} \text{rad}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 252, 920, 270]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 282, 180, 301]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 281, 599, 300]]<|/det|>
The rotation of the rod causes the thread to twist.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 295, 913, 315]]<|/det|>
The torque \(T\) (in Nm) required to twist the thread through an angle \(\beta\) (in rad) is given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[418, 326, 581, 345]]<|/det|>
\[T = 9.3\times 10^{-10}\times \beta .\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 357, 881, 377]]<|/det|>
Calculate the torque in the thread when sphere L is positioned as shown in Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[510, 508, 920, 527]]<|/det|>
<form>torque = .................................................... Nm [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 540, 144, 559]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 540, 680, 559]]<|/det|>
The distance between the centres of spheres S and L is \(6.0 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 555, 692, 574]]<|/det|>
The mass of sphere S is \(7.5 \text{g}\) and the mass of sphere L is \(1.3 \text{kg}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 586, 181, 604]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 586, 920, 619]]<|/det|>
By equating the torque in (b)(ii) to the moment about the thread produced by gravitational attraction between the spheres, calculate a value for the gravitational constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[354, 887, 920, 906]]<|/det|>
<form>gravitational constant = ................................................. Nm²kg⁻² [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 72, 180, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 918, 104]]<|/det|>
Suggest why the total force between the spheres may not be equal to the force calculated using Newton's law of gravitation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 173, 920, 191]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 670, 91]]<|/det|>
The first law of thermodynamics may be expressed in the form

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 102, 549, 121]]<|/det|>
\[\Delta U = q + w.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 181, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 133, 507, 152]]<|/det|>
State, for a system, what is meant by:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 165, 260, 183]]<|/det|>
1. \(+q\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 203, 917, 245]]<|/det|>
<form>2. + $W$.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 336, 920, 355]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 365, 181, 384]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 365, 628, 384]]<|/det|>
State what is represented by a negative value of \(\Delta U\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[845, 425, 920, 444]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 865, 92]]<|/det|>
An ideal gas, sealed in a container, undergoes the cycle of changes shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 106, 912, 572]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 590, 532, 609]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 621, 910, 640]]<|/det|>
At point A, the gas has volume \(2.4 \times 10^{-3} \text{m}^3\), pressure \(1.6 \times 10^5 \text{Pa}\) and temperature \(300 \text{K}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 653, 920, 702]]<|/det|>
The gas is compressed suddenly so that no thermal energy enters or leaves the gas during the compression. The amount of work done is \(480 \text{J}\) so that, at point B, the gas has volume \(8.7 \times 10^{-4} \text{m}^3\), pressure \(6.6 \times 10^5 \text{Pa}\) and temperature \(450 \text{K}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 714, 920, 747]]<|/det|>
The gas is now cooled at constant volume so that, between points B and C, 1100 J of thermal energy is transferred. At point C, the gas has pressure \(1.6 \times 10^5 \text{Pa}\) and temperature 110K.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 761, 462, 778]]<|/det|>
Finally, the gas is returned to point A.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A spring is hung vertically from a fixed point. A mass M is hung from the other end of the spring, as illustrated in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[349, 114, 645, 288]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 310, 532, 327]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 341, 920, 375]]<|/det|>
The mass is displaced downwards and then released. The subsequent motion of the mass is simple harmonic.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 387, 715, 406]]<|/det|>
The variation with time \(t\) of the length \(L\) of the spring is shown in Fig. 3.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[180, 415, 816, 740]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 757, 534, 776]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 789, 146, 807]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 789, 210, 807]]<|/det|>
State:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 820, 180, 838]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

one time at which the mass is moving with maximum speed

<form>time = .................................................... $s$

<form>time = .................................................... $s$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[910, 912, 920, 930]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
The mass M is now suspended from two springs, each identical to that in Fig. 3.1, as shown in Fig. 3.3.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[336, 114, 655, 285]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 301, 534, 320]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 333, 920, 367]]<|/det|>
Suggest and explain the change, if any, in the period of oscillation of the mass. A numerical answer is not required.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 471, 920, 490]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 10]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 72, 96, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 725, 92]]<|/det|>
State what is meant by the specific acoustic impedance of a medium.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 195, 141, 214]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 195, 920, 230]]<|/det|>
A parallel beam of ultrasound of intensity \(I_0\) is incident on the boundary between two media A and B, as illustrated in Fig. 4.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[203, 240, 784, 361]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 380, 532, 399]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 412, 833, 432]]<|/det|>
The two media A and B have specific acoustic impedances \(Z_{\mathrm{A}}\) and \(Z_{\mathrm{B}}\) respectively.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 427, 690, 446]]<|/det|>
The intensity of the beam transmitted through the boundary is \(I_{\mathrm{T}}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 458, 314, 476]]<|/det|>
State how the ratio

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[364, 483, 631, 520]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{\mathrm{intensity} I_{\mathrm{T}} \mathrm{of} \mathrm{transmitted} \mathrm{beam}}{\mathrm{intensity} I_{\mathrm{0}} \mathrm{of} \mathrm{incident} \mathrm{beam}}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 535, 566, 555]]<|/det|>
depends on the relative magnitudes of \(Z_{\mathrm{A}}\) and \(Z_{\mathrm{B}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[88, 691, 121, 710]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 691, 740, 710]]<|/det|>
The linear absorption (attenuation) coefficient \(\mu\) of medium B is \(23 \text{m}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 721, 920, 755]]<|/det|>
Calculate the thickness of medium B required to reduce the intensity of the ultrasound beam to \(34\%\) of its initial intensity in medium B.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[485, 891, 920, 910]]<|/det|>
<form>thickness = .................................................... m [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 923, 920, 940]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 715, 91]]<|/det|>
For a signal transmitted along an optic fibre, state what is meant by:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 183, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 102, 292, 121]]<|/det|>
attenuation

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 135, 920, 156]]<|/det|>
<form>........................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[845, 163, 920, 181]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 194, 180, 212]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 195, 248, 212]]<|/det|>
noise.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 319, 181, 337]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[178, 319, 920, 354]]<|/det|>
The initial section of the transmission line for a signal from a telephone exchange is illustrated in Fig. 5.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[176, 361, 833, 536]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 556, 532, 574]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 5.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 588, 863, 606]]<|/det|>
At the exchange, the input signal to the transmission line has a power of \(2.5 \times 10^{-3} \text{W}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 619, 920, 652]]<|/det|>
After the signal has travelled a distance of \(52\mathrm{km}\) along the transmission line, the power of the signal is \(7.8\times 10^{-16}\mathrm{W}.\) The signal is then amplified.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 666, 183, 684]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 666, 824, 684]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 490, 866, 508]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 505, 403, 523]]<|/det|>
The potential at point P is \(V.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 536, 920, 570]]<|/det|>
